text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits the revised IRM 5.12.5, Federal Tax Liens, Redemptions.

Editorial changes made throughout. Updated terminology and references to IRM sections and forms. Revised wording for clariﬁcation and compliance with writing standards. Corrected formatting issues. Rearranged subsections, merged duplicate passages, and restructured paragraphs within subsections for ﬂow.
5.12.5.2.2 and 5.12.5.2.3: Switched subsections for ﬂow.
5.12.5.2.3: Modiﬁed title. Moved sentence regarding approval authority to 5.12.5.2.6. Incorporated paragraphs from former subsection 5.12.5.5.3.
5.12.5.2.8: Formerly subsection 5.12.5.5.4, retitled for clarity.

5.12.5.4: Updated title. Inserted paragraphs about the use of Form 4376 and the assignment of a redemption serial number. Moved paragraphs regarding Budget Office and Beckley Finance Center to new section 5.12.5.5 about the revolving fund.
5.12.5.7: Inserted paragraph on Advisory responsibility previously in 5.12.5.6.2.
5.12.5.8: Revised language for minimum dollar amount for release of redemption rights to accommodate variance by U.S. Attorney’s office.
5.12.5-1: Converted information previously in Exhibit 5.12.5-3 to sample memo.
This material supersedes IRM 5.12.5, dated June 11, 2010, and Interim Guidance Memo SBSE-05-0714- 0040, titled Change to Deﬁnition of Designated Payment Code 07, dated July 22, 2014.
Table of Contents

) The Internal Revenue Service has the right to redeem real property sold through a foreclosure action initiated by a third party that has a priority Overview over the federal tax lien. • For judicial foreclosures, redemption is authorized under Title
U.S.C. §
(c). • For non-judicial foreclosures, redemption is authorized under IRC
) The time period for a redemption after a foreclosure sale, with respect to a non-judicial or judicial foreclosure, is
calendar days or the period allowable for redemption under State law, whichever is longer. (

) IRS redemptions can beneﬁt both the government and the taxpayer. The goal of redemption is for the property to be resold for an amount substantial to pay off the foreclosing instrument and apply funds to the taxpayer’s The key to a successful redemption case is locating a guaranteed bidder willing to advance a deposit (generally in the amount of twenty (
) percent) the amount bid. (
) This IRM contains procedural information on judicial and non-judicial redemp- tions. Many of the procedures are intertwined with those mentioned in IRM
, Judicial and Non-Judicial Foreclosures. Note: For procedures related to redeeming acquired property from seizure and sale, see in IRM
, Acquired Property and Property Redeemed by the United States. (
) Collection Advisory has primary responsibility for conducting redemption tigations. Advisory coordinates with a revenue officer and/or a Property
For procedures related to redeeming acquired property from seizure sale, see in IRM

, Acquired Property and Property Redeemed United States. Collection Advisory has primary responsibility for conducting redemption tigations. Advisory coordinates with a revenue officer and/or a Property Appraisal and Liquidation Specialist (PALS) when ﬁeld investigation is necessary. The primary role of the revenue officer and/or PALS is to assist in the government’s interest and recommending the appropriate action to out the investigation. Each Area, with the concurrence of the Advisory Territory Manager TM), is responsible for establishing criteria for conducting redemption gations. Throughout this IRM, references to the rights of a purchaser at the sale generally can be applied to a successor in interest to the A redemption generally involves the following elements: • Monitoring the foreclosure sale • Conducting the redemption investigation • Determining if there is sufficient property value to consider • Considering the release of the right of redemption, if requested • Notifying the foreclosure sale purchaser • Securing a guaranteed bidder for an IRS redemption sale • Obtaining money from the revolving fund to cover the foreclosure amount and allowable expenses • Redeeming the property from the foreclosure sale purchaser • Recording property ownership documents • Conducting the redemption sale of the property
Each Area, with the concurrence of the Advisory Territory Manager (Advisory TM), is responsible for establishing criteria for conducting redemption investi-
Throughout this IRM, references to the rights of a purchaser at the foreclosure sale generally can be applied to a successor in interest to the purchaser.
Facilitating the transfer of property ownership to the successful the redemption sale

Completing paperwork The Advisory executive determines the dollar criteria for working investigations. This responsibility can be delegated to the Advisory The criteria for redemption investigations is based on the balance of assessment (UBA) and the government’s equity in the redemption purposes. If this criteria is not met, then no initiated. At the discretion of Advisory leadership, this criteria is change contingent upon factors that include:
Geographic considerations
Economic conditions
Type of property involved
Value of the United States’ right to redeem
Practical impact of local law
Any other factor deemed signiﬁcant by leadership
The Advisory executive determines the dollar criteria for working redemption investigations. This responsibility can be delegated to the Advisory TM.
investigations. This responsibility can be delegated to the Advisory TM. (

) The criteria for redemption investigations is based on the taxpayer’s unpaid balance of assessment (UBA) and the government’s equity in the property for redemption purposes. If this criteria is not met, then no investigation is initiated. At the discretion of Advisory leadership, this criteria is subject to
Geographic considerations
Economic conditions
Type of property involved
Value of the United States’ right to redeem
Practical impact of local law
Any other factor deemed signiﬁcant by

Once established, the criteria are subject to periodic review to ensure remain relevant. Advisory has the primary responsibility for redemption investigations, Revenue Officers may need to do redemption investigations while cases. Once it is determined that a redemption investigation is warranted, open Non-Field Other Investigation (NFOI) -
, Redemption, on ICS within (

) calendar days. Document information of the investigation and the ICS history, including: • Foreclosure sale date • Foreclosure sale purchaser • Last date to redeem • Amount needed to redeem Advisory should utilize whatever resources are deemed appropriate by Advisory managers to gather all available information regarding the the property, before requesting assistance from either a revenue officer PALS. When considering whether to recommend redemption, the investigator take the following actions.
Follow the guidelines in the table below to determine whether to proceed with a redemption investigation. Revenue officers and/or PALS report their ﬁndings

If the FMV... Then ... Reasonably exceeds the: Consider redemption • amount paid by the foreclosure sale purchaser, AND • amount of all liens senior to the fore- closing encumbrance Is less than either the: Do not consider • amount paid by the foreclosure sale redemption purchaser, AND/OR • amount of all liens senior to the fore- closing encumbrance.
Note: The overall objective in establishing the criteria is to ensure that a tion is made whenever appropriate and that resources are used efficiently. (

) While considering redemption, be alert to whether liens prior to the encumbrance are outstanding and, if so, whether arrangements have been made to satisfy or make payments on them. The IRS has no authority to the Revolving Fund to make direct payments on such encumbrances. (
) Before redeeming, review for potential toxic waste problems. If the potential exists, clean up costs should be considered. (
) When tentatively deciding to recommend redemption, take the following actions. a. Notify the purchaser of their rights. See IRM

, Foreclosure Sale Purchaser Reimbursement Rights. Note: Inquiries about possible redemptions frequently lead to lien payoffs and releases of our right of redemption. b. Locate parties interested in submitting agreements to bid for the Utilize PALS, as necessary, to locate prospective bidders. See IRM
, Soliciting Agreements to Bid. (

) During the course of a redemption investigation, when the foreclosure sale purchaser, guaranteed bidder, redemption sale purchaser, other participant, taxpayer, representative, or IRS employee misses a speciﬁc deadline, submitting required documentation and/or payment, follow-up is based on meeting the Service’s requirements to maintain its standing in the
Note: The overall objective in establishing the criteria is to ensure that a redemp- tion is made whenever appropriate and that resources are used efficiently.

) During the course of a redemption investigation, when the foreclosure sale purchaser, guaranteed bidder, redemption sale purchaser, other participant, taxpayer, representative, or IRS employee misses a speciﬁc deadline, including submitting required documentation and/or payment, follow-up is based on meeting the Service’s requirements to maintain its standing in the proceeding
Federal Tax and should be initiated no later than fourteen (
) calender days after the missed deadline. This follow-up includes closing the case if this action is propriate (
) When circumstances dictate, the employee should use problem solving negotiation techniques, and in so doing consider the taxpayer/POA/third perspective when working toward case resolution. (
) Any written notiﬁcation or other communication should address the issue(s) clearly and in a language understandable to someone unfamiliar with IRS terms, acronyms and jargon. (
) When redemption is considered, the IRS must notify the purchaser of the property at the foreclosure sale (or the successor in interest, if applicable) Sale their right to reimbursement. (

) In addition to being reimbursed for the amount paid toward the purchase Rights interest), the purchaser has the right to request reimbursement for certain payments made to a senior lienholder if the Government redeems the and a reimbursement request is submitted that meets the requirements of regulations. Note: The regulations governing reimbursement for payments to a senior impose certain special requirements on both the IRS and the purchaser therefore, must be viewed separately from those that govern other to which the purchaser may be entitled if the property is redeemed. (
) Notice to the purchaser about the redemption must be hand-delivered or by certiﬁed or registered mail. (

) A purchaser of real property at a foreclosure sale may request for an amount equal to: • the expenses necessarily incurred to maintain the property minus • any income realized from the property plus a reasonable rental value of property (to the extent the property is used by, or with the consent of, foreclosure sale purchaser or is rented at less than its reasonable rental value). (

) The foreclosure sale purchaser has the right to be reimbursed for necessary maintenance expenses (or fees) incurred during the time they are in sion of the property. These expenses are subject to review and can be recommended for approval either in whole or in part . (

) Speciﬁc maintenance expenses that may be considered are those utilized to keep the property safe and intact, such as those mentioned throughout this IRM. Expenses not listed can be considered as long as reasonable prudence is administered when considering the expense. Examples of expenses to consider include: • Recording fees • Insurance • New locks for security purposes • Required repairs needed to ﬁx damage that would directly impact the of the property during this period of time (

) Do not consider expenses to enhance or improve the property. Examples of unallowable expenses include: • Cleaning • Utilities (unless required to keep property from being damaged) • Accrued property taxes (unless foreclosure proceedings are in effect) (

) Any type of maintenance expense claimed must be veriﬁed and justiﬁed as necessary under the circumstances. Unusual claims should be discussed agreed to by the manager. If the legality of the expense is being challenged, Area Counsel concurrence is also needed. (
) The foreclosure sale purchaser’s reimbursement request must be mailed or delivered: • to the IRS office speciﬁed in the Letter
• no later than ﬁfteen (
) calendar days after the IRS sends Letter

) The request must contain the following information: • Written itemized statement • Claimant signature • Amount paid to the senior lienholder for which reimbursement is claimed • Supporting evidence • Waiver or other document that will be effective upon redemption to discharge the property from, or transfer to the United States, any interest or lien on the property arising under local law with respect to the made to the senior lienholder.
Written itemized statement
Claimant signature
Amount paid to the senior lienholder for which reimbursement is claimed
Supporting evidence

Waiver or other document that will be effective upon redemption to discharge the property from, or transfer to the United States, any interest in or lien on the property arising under local law with respect to the payment made to the senior lienholder.
Federal Tax (
) Review the reimbursement request for adequacy and promptly contact the purchaser to correct any obvious defects. As necessary, refer the request for through Advisory to Area Counsel for review. (

) The government will not reimburse a purchaser for any expenses or to a senior lienholder if the request is not timely mailed or delivered. if the purchaser shows reasonable cause, and the Advisory Territory consents, the purchaser may request an extension for a reasonable period submit, amend, or supplement a request for reimbursement. Any such extension request must be submitted before expiration of the applicable for redemption. (
) The amount of reimbursement requested may be denied or approved, in or in part. The Advisory Group Manager has ﬁnal approval whether the expenses are allowable. (
) If the IRS exercises its right to redeem the property, the amount requested reimbursement must be approved and paid from the Revolving Fund. (
) If the right to redeem is not exercised or a request for reimbursement is withdrawn, promptly return to the purchaser the waiver or other document certiﬁed or registered mail or by hand delivery. (

) Requests for reimbursement generally should be denied only in cases one or more of the following occur: • Reimbursement request was not timely made and reasonable cause not Request shown • Waiver or other document required to be submitted with the request was not submitted or was unsatisfactory • Evidence of payment to a bona ﬁde senior lienholder or support for claimed amount was not submitted or was unsatisfactory (

) If reimbursement is denied, the purchaser must be notiﬁed of the decision writing. The denial notiﬁcation must: • be signed by the Advisory TM, • state the reason for the denial, and • be sent by certiﬁed or registered mail or hand-delivered within thirty (
) calendar days after receipt of the reimbursement request, or ﬁfteen (
) calendar days before expiration of the applicable period for redemption, whichever is later. (

) When a reimbursement request is denied, the request shall be treated as having been withdrawn by the purchaser and to redeem the property the shall tender only the amount otherwise payable. Note: At the discretion of the Advisory TM and upon resolution of the disagree- ment, payment of the amount previously denied may be made after the redemption of the property.
If the IRS exercises its right to redeem the property, the amount requested for reimbursement must be approved and paid from the Revolving Fund.
Reimbursement request was not timely made and reasonable cause not shown
Waiver or other document required to be submitted with the reimbursement request was not submitted or was unsatisfactory
Evidence of payment to a bona ﬁde senior lienholder or support for other claimed amount was not submitted or was unsatisfactory

percent annum from the date of such sale until the anticipated redemption date • If applicable, the amount of a payment made by the purchaser (or successor in interest) after the foreclosure sale to a holder of a lien to that foreclosed • If applicable, the amount equal to the expenses necessarily incurred in connection with such property after the sale but before redemption the income from such property and MINUS a reasonable rental value such property (to the extent such property was used or allowed to be by the purchaser) (
) Before recommending redemption of real property, the employee assigned work the investigation must obtain at least one offer to bid on the property. Agreements to (
) Mail Letter

, Information for Prospective Purchasers of Real Property, any parties that may potentially be interested in the purchasing the The letter can be mailed to those shown on the public auction bidders list. Contact the PALS for information on the bidders list. (

) The offer to bid must be: • a written agreement, • for an amount that is sufficient to ensure that redemption will be in the Government’s interest, and • consistent with the method by which the Government intends to sell property. (
) Give the prospective bidder the opportunity to inspect the property, if and to inquire about its condition and title. (
) Commencing the redemption process without a secured or guaranteed is prohibited unless prior approval is secured from the executive-level immediately over Advisory. See IRM
, Delegation Order
(Rev. (
) Commercial advertising to solicit bids may be judiciously used to broaden ﬁeld of potential bidders. Advertising must be approved in advance by the Advertising group manager. (

) The advertisement, regardless of size, should be limited to a statement as:“Prospective Purchasers of Real Property . . . the Internal Revenue considering the redemption of real property located at (given address) . . . (
) The advertising can provide a statement and contact number for parties interested in being a guaranteed bidder, but who are interested in the property at the redemption sale. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

percent per annum from the date of such sale until the anticipated redemption date • If applicable, the amount of a payment made by the purchaser (or successor in interest) after the foreclosure sale to a holder of a lien senior to that foreclosed • If applicable, the amount equal to the expenses necessarily incurred in connection with such property after the sale but before redemption MINUS the income from such property and MINUS a reasonable rental value of such property (to the extent such property was used or allowed to be used by the purchaser)

, Contracting for Services, for securing advertising. (
) The taxpayer’s account will not be debited for these expenses even if the property is not sold. (

) Redemption recommendations must include a guaranteed purchaser, the redemption is approved by the appropriate executive. Additionally, this Bid spective purchaser is generally required to submit an “Agreement to Bid” with a deposit of at least twenty (
) percent of the bid amount. (

) The guaranteed bid must be an amount determined to be reasonable in tionship to the cost of redeeming, maintaining, and selling the property. amount does not need to represent forced sale value. Note: Refer to IRM
, Establishment of Minimum Bid, for additional tion regarding “forced sale value.” (

) The amount calculated as a guaranteed bid is subject to approval by the ployee’s manager. Final approval rests with the Advisory GM. If the ﬁeld manager and the Advisory GM are unable to concur with the guaranteed amount, then the ﬁnal decision will rest with the Advisory TM for the area which the property is located. (

) Any person agreeing to bid at a redemption sale should complete Form Agreement to Bid for Redemptions. Ensure potential bidders are fully Submitted With the provisions in the event of default to Bid (
) The prospective purchaser must guarantee their performance with a non- refundable deposit equal to at least twenty (
) percent of the agreed bid amount., (
) A deposit of less than

percent may be approved by the Advisory Group Manager with Advisory Territory Manager concurrence. At a minimum, this include written veriﬁcation that this was discussed and agreed upon by levels of management. • A decision to accept less than the

percent must be made based on facts of the case, with the understanding that there is a greater risk to government based on the potential for a bidder to default on a small amount. • In no case should the deposit be less than $
unless the deposit amount represents
percent of the agreed bid. (

) The deposit should be made by a certiﬁed, cashier’s, or treasurer’s check drawn on any bank or trust company incorporated under the laws of the States or under the laws of any state, territory, or possession of the United States, or by a postal, bank, express, or telegraph money order. • Certiﬁcates of Deposit and irrevocable letters of credit are also if approved in advance by Area Counsel. Care should be exercised in accepting and monitoring such instruments because of the period of which they are negotiable is generally limited.

) Any redemption recommendation without a secured/guaranteed purchaser must be approved by the Advisory executive. . (
) Upon approval of the redemption, Advisory assigns a redemption serial number. See IRM
, Redemption Serial Numbers. (

) Advisory forwards the original and one copy (with all necessary enclosures) the report to the local Area Counsel for concurrence of the amount to redeem and determination of the title the United States will acquire from purchaser when redemption is made. This should occur as soon as but not later than thirty (

) calendar days from the date of the sale. Note: This deadline is to be used as a guideline and can be further discussed the local Area Counsel. With their concurrence, deadlines can be on a case-by-case basis. (

) Upon receipt of Area Counsel concurrence, forward a copy of the report and the Area Counsel approval determination to the Advisory TM for formation purposes and retain the original in the redemption ﬁle. Note: The need for forwarding this information is at the discretion of the Advisory TM. (

) Any redemption recommendation without a secured/guaranteed purchaser must be approved by the Advisory executive. . (

, Redemption Serial Numbers. (

) Advisory forwards the original and one copy (with all necessary enclosures) of the report to the local Area Counsel for concurrence of the amount necessary to redeem and determination of the title the United States will acquire from the purchaser when redemption is made. This should occur as soon as possible, but not later than thirty (
) calendar days from the date of the sale.

Advisory is responsible for documenting the ICS history with information regarding the redemption including the date of redemption; the amount of the redemption; the amount of tax liability satisﬁed; and the date and place the certiﬁcate of redemption was recorded.

) Since the revolving fund is not governed by ﬁscal year the ﬁles are geographically and by territory. (
) The Advisory TM will determine where the serial numbers are maintained monitored. (
) When a recommendation is made to exercise the right of redemption and it require an expenditure of $

or more to redeem the property, the Advisory GM must consider the beneﬁts of either assigning an Other Requiring tion(OI) to a PALS and/or enlisting the services of an IRS appraisal or More a professional appraisal ﬁrm. This decision must be documented prior to approving and forwarding the recommendation for Advisory TM approval. (

) In addition, when there is a question as to the extent of property the Advisory GM is encouraged to consider the use of a professional to establish the exact nature of the property to be redeemed. The decision to utilize these services should be documented and attached to the Form
Otherwise, the results of the appraisal and/or survey must be as a part of the investigation. (

) Under certain circumstances, and as warranted, it may be appropriate to contract out for a professional survey. This should be considered with tions involving acreage, multi-structure parcels, or any other property where would prove to be in the Government’s best interest. A professional survey may prove beneﬁcial when considering the ﬁeld employee’s determination exact boundaries as well as ensuring property is included or excluded in investigation. Contracting professional property appraisal services should be considered when the services of a PALS or valuation engineer are not readily available, or if specialized expertise is required to accurately the value of a unique property. (

) The initial decision to utilize an outside contractor generally is made by the revenue officer or PALS and their GM. The feasibility of contracting out then be discussed with the advisor and Advisory GM. The Advisory and group managers should be in agreement that circumstances warrant contractor consideration, although the ﬁnal decision rests with Advisory. If two managers are in disagreement, then the ﬁnal decision rests with the Advisory TM.

Example: The second redemption investigation in the North Atlantic Territory (01), Advisory group (04) is numbered 01RED040002.
a professional appraisal ﬁrm. This decision must be documented prior to approving and forwarding the recommendation for Advisory TM approval. (

) In addition, when there is a question as to the extent of property boundaries, the Advisory GM is encouraged to consider the use of a professional surveyor to establish the exact nature of the property to be redeemed. The decision not to utilize these services should be documented and attached to the Form
Otherwise, the results of the appraisal and/or survey must be included as a part of the investigation. (

) Under certain circumstances, and as warranted, it may be appropriate to contract out for a professional survey. This should be considered with redemp- tions involving acreage, multi-structure parcels, or any other property where it would prove to be in the Government’s best interest. A professional survey may prove beneﬁcial when considering the ﬁeld employee’s determination of exact boundaries as well as ensuring property is included or excluded in the investigation. Contracting professional property appraisal services should also be considered when the services of a PALS or valuation engineer are not readily available, or if specialized expertise is required to accurately determine the value of a unique property. (

) The initial decision to utilize an outside contractor generally is made by the revenue officer or PALS and their GM. The feasibility of contracting out should then be discussed with the advisor and Advisory GM. The Advisory and ﬁeld group managers should be in agreement that circumstances warrant outside contractor consideration, although the ﬁnal decision rests with Advisory. If the two managers are in disagreement, then the ﬁnal decision rests with the Advisory TM.

) A revolving fund was created for the redemption of real property by the States based on the Government’s federal tax lien. See IRC

) By exercising its right of redemption, the Government can purchase property sold at distress prices and resell the property at a proﬁt. In some instances procedure is the only means by which Federal tax liabilities can be (

) The SB/SE Field Budget Office determines the availability of funds and the priority for disbursement when available funds may be insufficient to meet or more requests. This serves to avoid depletion of the fund. (

) To effectuate a redemption of property, there must be an actual payment of money as distinguished from a mere proposal or proposition to pay it and documents providing evidence of the redemption must be properly recorded. (
) Delivery of the check for the redemption to the purchaser must be done promptly upon receipt of the check from the revolving fund. (

) The employee who has been designated to tender the amount required to redeem must be accompanied by at least one witness -- preferably an Area Counsel attorney, or revenue officer, but any IRS employee may (
) An acknowledgment of receipt of the check should be secured from the purchaser, if possible. (

) In the event that the tender to redeem is refused, prepare a report of the action and forward through Advisory to Area Counsel for an advisory opinion and guidance as to the next action to be taken. (

) The report should include a request for instructions as to the immediate sition of the check that had been tendered. a. Place the redemption check in a location meeting the Minimum Standards (MPS) as outlined in IRM
, Minimum Protection Standards. Depending on the type of payment, this is generally a Security (SP-
or SP-

) requirement. Generally, an acceptable location would be a qualiﬁed safe used by Advisory or Criminal Investigation. payment will remain in a secured place until advice is received from counsel regarding the action to be taken. b. Prepare Form
for safekeeping of the property. Note: The period to redeem (i.e.,

calendar days from the date of foreclosing sale or the State allowed period, whichever is longer) may expire while check is being held by the IRS. To perfect the redemption of the property, Certiﬁcate of Redemption must be properly recorded prior to the the redemption period. See IRM
, Certiﬁcate of Redemption. (

) It is essential that a timely tender of the amount required to redeem be to the proper person. If the person who purchased the property at the sure sale has conveyed it to another, the IRS may still redeem the property from the subsequent purchaser (“successor in interest”). The advice of Area Counsel should be solicited to ascertain the proper party and amount to be tendered. (
) When the IRS executes its redemption rights, evidence of the redemption be recorded in the public record. (

) After the determination to redeem is approved, Advisory contacts the local official designated by law to determine the documents necessary to show redemption. If no such official has been designated by local law, the official fails to issue the necessary documents, or there are no standard documents under local law, the Advisory TM is authorized to issue a certiﬁcate of tion. ) Consult Area Counsel for guidance as to the form of the certiﬁcate to be in each jurisdiction. (
) Preparation of the certiﬁcate of redemption is done by the advisor work the investigation. (

) The authority to sign a certiﬁcate of redemption is delegated to the TM. In cases where there is no guaranteed purchaser, the certiﬁcate of re- demption must be signed by the IRS executive over Advisory. See IRM
, Delegation Order
(Rev.

) The certiﬁcate of redemption may be prepared either before the check is delivered to the payee or immediately afterwards provided sufficient time to permit ﬁling the certiﬁcate before the redemption period expires. (
) The certiﬁcate will be prepared in duplicate by Advisory and disposed of follows: • Original is ﬁled with recording official. • Duplicate is retained by Advisory. (

) Document the ICS history about the redemption, including the following: • Guaranteed bidder or reason, and approval authority obtained, for tion without a guaranteed bidder • Amount paid for the redemption • Date of redemption • From whom the property was redeemed and, if applicable, reason not redeemed from the foreclosure sale purchaser • The date and place the certiﬁcate was recorded (

) Advisory must promptly cause the certiﬁcate to be recorded in the proper recording office. Advisory incorporates the assistance of a revenue officer PALS, who must: • ensure that the certiﬁcate is personally delivered to the recording • verify recordation of the certiﬁcate, and • provide the recording data to Advisory. (

) If the state where the real property is redeemed has not designated an which the certiﬁcate should be recorded, the certiﬁcate shall be ﬁled in the office of the clerk of the United States District Court for the judicial district which the redeemed property is situated. (
) Consult Area Counsel, as needed, for the proper place for recording the cate in each jurisdiction. (
) Advisory is responsible for periodic follow-up action until the redeemed property is disposed of. The frequency of follow-up activity is determined the Advisory TM. (

) The Advisory TM should periodically request status reports from the office involved in the redemption investigation. If the investigation is to a revenue officer or PALS, Advisory should obtain necessary status as required by the Advisory TM. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The Advisory GM ensures that redeemed property located within the jurisdic- tion of the area office is appropriately maintained. a. Maintenance expenses or fees may be incurred while administering redeemed property. Refer to IRM

, Foreclosure Sale Purchaser Reimbursement Rights, for guidance on appropriate maintenance expenses. b. Ordinary and necessary expenses may be incurred in the preservation the property. These expenses may include the cost of minor repairs to property if deemed necessary for its preservation. The procedures to the protection of property during the period of seizure also apply to redeemed property. Refer to IRM
, Protecting the Property Seizure. (

) Estimated expenses expected to be incurred in connection with the mainte- nance, preservation, and sale of the property should be documented and in the same manner as is required with seized property. Review the proce- dures as discussed in IRM
, Contracting for Services $
and Under. (

) Redeemed property may be leased to a third party if it is determined that it be in the government’s possession for an extended period of time and that government’s interest will best be served by such action. (

) The initial determination to lease the property is made by the advisor with currence from the Advisory GM and is based upon the circumstances of the investigation. Approval of the Advisory TM must be secured before the is offered. (

) When it is determined that redeemed property will be leased and a lessee has been secured, Advisory must request assistance from Area Counsel in preparing the lease agreement. The lease agreement: • generally should not be for more than one year, but may be renewable, • should not contain any provision that prevents selling the property, to the lease, at any time a suitable purchaser is found, • should specify that payments be made by certiﬁed or cashier’s check or money order and sent directly to Advisory, and • should contain provisions in the event of default. (

) Advisory should furnish Area Counsel with the following information: • Name and address of the lessee • Description and location of property • How property was acquired by the United States • Period of the lease • Terms of payment (i.e., amount, manner, due date and place of • Any special provisions to be contained in the lease (e.g., property nance, authorized alterations, improvements, etc.) • Any other pertinent information (

) Upon receipt of the concurrence from Area Counsel, the Advisory GM the lease to see that it conforms to the intent of the parties involved and forwards the original and duplicate to the Advisory TM for approval. (
) After Advisory TM approval, take the following actions. (

and regulations, and that the information reported is a true and correct record of the sale proceedings (

provide that, upon payment in full of the price, the IRS will issue a deed to the purchaser. (
) Advisory prepares the deed and forwards it to Area Counsel for review. (

(a) and in the same manner as funds realized from proceeds. Legitimate property maintenance, preservation, and sale incurred while bringing the redeemed property to sale are deducted ﬁrst the net amount is credited to the taxpayer’s account. (

(b), the person entitled to receive the funds. Interest is paid on surplus accordance with IRC

) A transmittal memorandum entitled “Proceeds from the Sale of Redeemed Property” should be promptly prepared after the completion of the sale by employee that conducted the sale. The memorandum must contain the following information: • Name and address of the taxpayer as shown on the Form

, which would have been submitted at the time redemption of the property was ommended • Name and address of the purchaser • Redemption sale price • Amount previously deposited with agreement to bid, if applicable • Identiﬁcation of remittances accompanying the transmittal, including the amount submitted with the winning bid, if applicable, and the amount remitted to pay the balance of the purchase price (

) Forward the memorandum and any accompanying remittances to Advisory review. Advisory is responsible for transmitting the memorandum, and the purchaser’s deposit (if any) to the Beckley Finance Center. (
) Advisory is also responsible for returning any other deposits submitted with unsuccessful “agreements to bid”, unless it was as a result of the depositor defaulting on the agreement. (

) When payment of the full purchase price is deferred, the purchaser’s deposit must be promptly forwarded to Beckley Finance Center for deposit to the revolving fund. This also applies to any deposit the purchaser may have with an “agreement to bid” prior to the sale. Advisory must ensure that the funds are correctly identiﬁed to Beckley Finance Center. (

) The purchaser’s payment of the balance must also be clearly identiﬁed for Beckley Finance Center. Duplication of memorandums is not required for of these scenarios, as long as Beckley Finance Center is understanding of what the funds represent. This can be accomplished through a telephone memorandum, or secured E-mail message. Advisory is responsible for ensuring that communication efforts with Beckley Finance Center are clearly understood and well documented in the ICS history. (
) Advisory must follow-up on the redemption within sixty (

) calendar days when money was received from the revolving fund. If there is a delay in repayment to the revolving fund, Advisory must notify Beckley Finance by memorandum or by secure E-mail, giving the redemption serial number, amount secured from the revolving fund, explanation for the delay, and the new estimated repayment date. Advisory must submit a status report to Beckley Finance Center every thirty (
) calendar days after the initial time period has expired. If, after
days, the amount remains unpaid, TM concurrence must be obtained for continued delays. (

) Authority to release any right of redemption is delegated to the Department Justice. The U.S. Government may release its right to redemption. This right cannot be sold, but the government can issue a certiﬁcate stating that it will not exercise the right to redeem. Generally, this requires payment of the value of the right of redemption as determined by Advisory. See IRM 1.2.44.5, Delegation Order 5-4 (Rev. 3).
Federal Tax (
) Applications for release of right of redemption should be submitted on ment of Justice Form OBD–
This form may be obtained from the DOJ for Release website (www.justice,gov). The form is also available to Collection as an ICS template. (

) The person requesting the release of right of redemption should submit the form, together with remittance and all necessary evidence, to the United Attorney for the area in which property subject to the right is located. (

) Upon receipt of an application for release of right of redemption, the U. S. Attorney should forward the original application, together with accompanying Applications documentation, to Advisory for veriﬁcation and recommendation. a. Applications received in the ﬁeld must be referred to Advisory for immediate transmittal to the United States Attorney. Advisory should the original of the application to begin their review. b. Applications received directly from any Federal agency may be by Advisory without ﬁrst being referred to the United States Attorney. (

) If an application is complete and proper, a ﬁeld investigation is not required, unless Advisory has information warranting an investigation. A ﬁeld investiga- tion will not be required on any application made by the Veterans Administration or any other Federal Agency regardless of value or use. An exception to the general rule may be determined by the Advisory GM with Advisory TM concurrence. In the rare case when a ﬁeld investigation is needed, Advisory should take the following actions. a. Promptly forward a copy of the application and any attachments via a Courtesy Investigation (OI) to the Area office having jurisdiction where property is located. b. Retain the original application with attachments for reference and purposes (

) Advisory will complete Part B of any application that does not require a ﬁeld investigation. Before a recommendation is made, Advisory must be satisﬁed that the appraisals were made by disinterested persons and that they were qualiﬁed to make appraisals. A memorandum report speciﬁcally stating that appraisers involved are disinterested and qualiﬁed will be prepared and accompany the application. In those cases in which the applicant is a agency, the appraised value furnished in the application will be accepted as correct and no statement will be necessary. (
) Applications requiring ﬁeld work shall be investigated promptly by a revenue officer or a PALS in order that ﬁnal disposition may be made by Advisory of thirty (

) calendar days. The employee assigned to investigate the shall verify each item contained in the application or which, in accordance the requirements prescribed, should have been contained in the application. (
) The investigating employee shall gather sufficient facts to make a determina- tion whether the United States should release its right of redemption. (
) In accordance with Delegation Order

) The investigating employee prepares a report of investigation when the gation is completed. The report should speciﬁcally state whether the involved are disinterested and qualiﬁed. The report is submitted to Advisory. (

or in memorandum form. (

) Upon receipt of the investigator’s report, Advisory reviews it to ensure that there is sufficient information to determine whether the right of redemption should be released. Advisory completes the application by indicating the ommendation and the manager’s approval. (

) Upon approval of the Advisory GM, forward the original and one copy of application, with copies of the investigator’s report attached, to the of Justice following local protocol. Maintain a copy of the application, the appraisals and a copy of the report. (

) DOJ or Advisory provides a copy of the approved application to the in exchange for payment of the amount required for the release of the right redemption. If DOJ receives the payment, it is forwarded to the lockbox for posting. Apply the payment to the taxpayer’s outstanding liability. (
) IRC
(d) provides for redemption, by the government, of real property in a non-judicial proceeding when the sale is made to satisfy a lien that is to that of the United States. The
-day period for redemption (or longer, State law so provides) is applicable. (

) In non-judicial actions, if it is determined that the right of redemption is valueless, no consideration shall be required to waive the government’s re- demption right, regardless if the request is from a private individual or agency. (
) Refer any questions as to the value of the right of redemption to Area for an advisory opinion. (

) Applications for release of right of redemption, and all necessary evidence, should be sent by applicants to the attention of the Advisory GM for the which property subject to the right is located. See Pub
, Collection Advisory Group Addresses. (
) Furnish potential applicants Pub
, How to Prepare Application to Property Secured by a Federal Tax Lien, as needed. (
) Process applications promptly, utilizing the services of Area Counsel as needed. (

) The investigating employee shall gather sufficient facts to determine the United States should release its right of redemption. The investigation be terminated when it is found that there is an encumbrance(s) prior to the foreclosing lien holder in excess of the value of the property.

) If an application is complete and proper, a ﬁeld investigation is not required unless there is information in Advisory that indicates such investigation is warranted. A ﬁeld investigation is not required on any application made by by Advisory Veterans Administration or any other federal agency regardless of value or use. Any exceptions to this are determined by the Advisory GM. (

) Certain situations may warrant ﬁeld involvement. When this occurs, issues an OI to either an RO or PALS to investigate. This decision should contingent upon factors such as geographic feasibility and the need for by the Field gative ﬁeld work. (

) Redemption OIs are routed directly to the ﬁeld revenue officer group the zip code. The group manager is required to treat these OIs as priority work. Redemption OIs must be assigned to a RO or PALS expeditiously to ensure that the Government’s interest is not compromised and that the gation is completed accurately and timely. Redemption OIs are exempt from existing case delivery parameters. (
) Redemption OIs must be investigated promptly in order that ﬁnal disposition may be made by Advisory within thirty (
) calendar days of receipt. The in- vestigating employee should verify every item contained in the application identify any item which should have been included in the application. (

) Except in unusual cases, it is not necessary for the revenue officer or PALS secure outside appraisals to establish the value of the property prior to a recommendation. If the situation arises to consider the services of an contractor, refer to the procedures outlined in IRM
, Outside tors. (
) The investigating employee prepares a redemption report upon completion the investigation. The report should be completed using Form
and of Investigation include a memorandum containing additional information, if necessary. (
) Forward the report, with the copy of the application and all exhibits, through the group manager to Advisory. (

) When a Release of the Right of Redemption is warranted, Advisory the appropriate document for signature approval. ICS templates are of Right of for this purpose. Issued a. If the Release of Right of Redemption is for value use the template tiﬁcate of Rel. of Right of Redemption (Value).” b. If the investigation has determined there is no value in the property to redeem, use the template “Certiﬁcate of Rel. of Right of Redemption (Valueless).” (
) Prepare the release in duplicate for approval. (
